data.caption: A community listens to local extension workers as they shell maize by hand in the Gangachara upazila of Rangpur district, Bangladesh.
Abdul, a farmer participating in a conservation agriculture extension plot in Rangpur, Bangladesh, shows off the latest crop.
A group of farmers are irrigating their land using an axial flow pump in Horinofolia in Bangladesh.

Md. Lalchan Shardar is a farmer from Rakudia, Barisal, Bangladesh. He is also a local service provider. He bought the Axial flow pump three months ago for TK.16,700. Lalchan has irrigated 25acres of land using the AFP. Previously these fields needed 12 hours of irrigation but using the AFP needs only 6 hours of irrigation. This saves time and fuel cost for him.

Women work together making roti, an unleavened flatbread made with wheat flour and eaten as a staple food, at their home in the village of Chapor, in the district of Dinajpur, Bangladesh. Families like theirs eat better thanks to improved varieties and farmer training from CIMMYT and its partners in Bangladesh.

Paresh Chandra Sarkar lives in Horinofolia in ward 26 under Barisal City Corporation in Bangladesh. He has been using the bed blanter for the last five months. This season he has planted corn on his land. Yield has increased since Paresh started using the bed planter.

Dr. P.K Malaker, principal scientific officer, examines wheat samples for signs of fungal growth in the plant pathology laboratory of the Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute's Wheat Research Centre in Dinajpur.
A community gathers to shell maize by hand in Rangpur district, Bangladesh.
This woman from Shovna village in southern Bangladesh, is harvesting her crop in an on-farm, farmer-managed experiment looking at new wheat varieties, planting dates, and nitrogen levels.
Farmer Sahiruddin Mohammad shows off his healthy stored wheat grain.
Tara Miah is a farmer from Rajguru in Rahamanbari union, Barisal, Bangladesh.
Maize intercropped with red amaranth (a leaf vegetable widely used in Bangladesh) from the CSISA-Bangladesh demonstration plot in the Mymensingh hub.
A little girl eats a freshly-made roti while the women of her family prepare more, at her home in the village of Chapor, in the district of Dinajpur, Bangladesh.
A farmer tends a long-term on-farm conservation agriculture trial for a rice-wheat-mungbean cropping system in Rajshahi district, Bangladesh.
A middleman offers maize and wheat grain and seed for sale at a market in Nur Islam, Dinajpur, Bangladesh.
A Bangladeshi woman grinds maize and chickpeas together as she prepares food.
Hafiz Uddin is farmer from Ulankhati, Tanpuna, Barisal. He used seeder fertilizer drills to plant mung beans on one acre of land.

Bangladeshi farmer Gopal Mohanta fetches water as part of his daily task of feeding and watering his livestock. He did not previously have animals, but was able to buy them thanks to a dramatic improvement in his livelihood after he began to work with CIMMYT.
RARS and CSISA-MA jointly organized training at Babuganj Upazilla Krishi Office, Barisal, Bangladesh. local service providers are trained on various modern agricultural techniques using multimedia.
Farmers in Bangladesh practicing traditional puddling of the soil before transplanting rice.
Wheat being prepared for phenotyping to determine its properties when grown in the field at a Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute research station in Rajshahi, Bangladesh.
Momataz and Lilofah (second and third from left) in Rangpur Bangladesh are leaders in a women farmers’ group that has been active for one year.
Women’s group leader Kalpon addresses men and women in the community.
A woman stands in the Vaishali district of Bihar, India. The female farmer is in a zero-till wheat plot.
Maize ears being stored in the traditional way in Yunnan Province, China. The harvest is hung in long bunches, usually in open sheds or along walls.
Maize ears being stored in the traditional way in Yunnan Province, China. The harvest is hung in long bunches, usually in open structures or along walls.
Stored maize ears hanging from a tree in Yunnan province, China.

Jorge Coronel (left), who leads the work of the cereals program of Ecuador’s National Institute of Agricultural Research (INIAP) in southern Ecuador, talks with a farmer leader about the wheat variety *INIAP Vivar 2010*, seen growing in his field in the background.
Banura Yabata weeding his field of improved variety dhagobae wheat
Basheda Jima harvesting fabel variety wheat in his family's field
Contracter operating his combine harvester in wheat field, Boru Lencha Village
David Kassahun research assistant Yodit Kebede examines weather station
Demewoz Negera, CIMMYT researcher
Farmer Abera Degefa and helpers transporting wheat from field to home
Farmer Galana Mulato harvests wheat research plot in farmers field
Farmer Melese Tsegaye blows to clean and select wheat seed in his field
Farmers group demostration drought tolerant DT maize plot in farmers field
A field worker at the Ethiopian Institute of Agricultural Research (EIAR) at Kulumsa, Ethiopia.
Grandmother harvests DT maize
Gutaa Bagara lead farmer walking in his field
Kameriya Mohamed slacking harvested wheat
Women farmers harvesting drought tolerant maize.
Newly released maize varieties on display
A woman at work drying wheat grain close to the Pusa site of the Borlaug Institute for South Asia (BISA), in the Indian state of Bihar.
Workers on Ram Shubagh Chaudhary's farm, in the village of Pokhar Binda, Maharajganj district, Uttar Pradesh, India, listen during a discussion on zero tillage with farmers and researchers.

Farmer Vipin Kumar points at a herd of Nilgai antelope (also known as Blue Bull) in his zero-tilled wheat field. Nilgais have increasingly become a menace in parts of Bihar by damaging the standing crops and causing huge losses to the farmers.
A farmer at work in a maize field close to the Pusa site of the Borlaug Institute for South Asia (BISA), in the Indian state of Bihar.

Farmer Ram Shubagh Chaudhary compares ears from early-sown wheat of variety PBW-502 (right, larger, sown on 2 November 2009), and the same variety sown 12 days later. Both were grown in his wheat fields, in the village of Pokhar Binda, Maharajganj district, Uttar Pradesh, India.
A farmer at work in a wheat field close to the Pusa site of the Borlaug Institute for South Asia (BISA), in the Indian state of Bihar.
A farmer at work weeding in a maize field close to the Pusa site of the Borlaug Institute for South Asia (BISA), in the Indian state of Bihar.
A farmer at work weeding in a maize field close to the Pusa site of the Borlaug Institute for South Asia (BISA), in the Indian state of Bihar.
Open grain storage, as shown in this photo from Karnal, Haryana, India, contributes to extensive post-harvest losses, especially under the current uncertain weather conditions
ACI hosts a demonstration of the reaper in Vajondi under Diknaigor Union, Gopalganj. In this session the farmers get familiar with a reaper and how efficiently it works.
Woman with golden fields
A zero tillage wheat field on the farm of Ram Shubagh Chaudhary, in the village of Pokhar Binda, Maharajganj district, Uttar Pradesh, India.

Children sit beside metal silos used for storing maize grain in Embu, Kenya. The silos are becoming a familiar sight for the children: they can be made by local artisans using readily-available materials, take up little space, and enable farmers to store their grain without losses.

Demonstrating the collection of small pieces of stem from stem rust-infected wheat plants in the laboratory, for use in the creation of a spore suspension in water for inoculation, at the Njoro research station, part of the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI).
Field workers at the Njoro research station in Kenya harvesting potatoes.

During a field visit, partners in the CIMMYT-led Drought Tolerant Maize for Africa (DTMA) project examine the high-throughput sheller now used as part of the high-precision, large-scale drought screening work carried out at the the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute's Kiboko Research Station.

categories: Water Efficient Maize for Africa- Phase II
data.caption: Stephen Mugo, principal scientist and maize breeder at CIMMYT Global Maize Program and coordinator of the Insect Resistant Maize for Africa (IRMA) and Water Efficient Maize for Africa(WEMA) projects, explains the process of effective nursery pollination to the trainees at the CIMMYT/KARI (Kenya Agricultural Research Institute) research station in Kiboko, Kenya.

Participants in a two week international training course on *Stem Rust Note Taking and Evaluation of Germplasm* in the field at Njoro research station, where the course was hosted by the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI).
The maize lethal necrosis (MLN) screening facility at the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI) Naivasha in Kenya.

Field workers at Njoro Agricultural Research Station in Kenya sowing wheat seed samples in international trials for screening for resistance to Ug99, the new and virulent strain of stem rust that emerged in Uganda in 1999.

categories: Water Efficient Maize for Africa- Phase II
data.caption: Joel Mbithi, farm manager of the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute's Kiboko Research Station, on an experimental maize plot.
Self-help group member shares benefits of QPM with fellow farmers, Kenya

*Demonstrating the small-scale, precise inoculation by spraying of wheat seedlings with stem rust using a stored spore sample in the laboratory, at the Njoro research station, part of the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI).
Demonstrating a simple and reliable technique to test if maize grain is dry enough to be loaded into metal silos for storage.
The virulent Ug99 strain of stem rust (Puccinia graminis) on wheat being screened at the Njoro research station in Kenya.
Wheat spike showing symptoms of stem rust (Puccinia graminis), in this case the virulent Ug99 race.
CIMMYT works together with the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI) in a crucial partnership on rust resistance at KARI’s Njoro Research Station.

Wheat rust expert Bob McIntosh, of the Plant Breeding Institute, University of Sydney, Australia, examining rust symptoms on a wheat line in the field at the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute's (KARI) Njoro research station in Kenya.

Children pose in a demonstration plot in a farmer's field in Malawi, where maize is cultivated using both conservation agriculture (CA) and conventional practices so that visitors can compare them. CA offers reliable harvests that mean freedom from hunger and food insecurity for children like these.
Comico Norteo landrace maize

A sign marks out a groundnut plot under conservation agriculture (CA) in the field of small-scale maize and mixed-crop farmer Belita Maleko, of the Mwansambo extension planning area, Nkhotakota zone, central Malawi.
Daimoniz Miondo is one of 800 farmers in Chipeni, Mvera Extension Planning Area, Dowa District, Malawi, who have adopted conservation agriculture in recent years.
Farmer Agnes Sendeza harvests maize cobs in Malawi.
Farmer Grace Malaitcha, from Zidyana, near Nkhotakota, Malawi, pictured in 2009 on her maize plot, which she cultivates using conservation agriculture (CA) practices.
*It’s amazing,* says farmer of conservation agriculture in Malawi
Farmer Bamusi Stambuli and his wife Sagulani, from Balaka, Malawi, display their store full of maize ears, of drought tolerant variety ZM 309.
Malawian farmer in her groundnut plot under conservation agriculture
Felix Twaya, of Lemu, Balaka, Malawi, farms about three acres of land. On one of his 0.1 hectare plots, he has been practicing conservation agriculture (CA) for three years.
Extension development officer Patrick Stanford listens to a group of farmers in Lemu, Balaka, Malawi.
Alta Gracia González, directora general de Agrícola El Cerro
CIMMYT staff members at work in the maize active collection in the Wellhausen-Anderson Plant Genetic Resources Center.
Atardecer en Angostura, Sinaloa
Maize ears and seed of the Mexican landrace *Bolita*, collected in the state of Oaxaca. It is richly variable, showing white, yellow, red and black colorations. It is flint in type.

Francisco Magallanes (far right), station superintendent at CIMMYT's headquarters at El Batán, Mexico, shows conservation agriculture (CA) in action to a group of canola producers from the Mexican state of Hidalgo, on an experimental plot at El Batán.

arolina Saint Pierre, CIMMYT wheat physiologist, carrying out a visual evaluation of the responses of wheat lines to water deficit, such as leaf rolling, in the field at CIMMYT's headquarters at El Batán, Mexico.

Mexican scientist J. Arahón Hernández Guzmán in his experimental plot of the Jala maize landrace, with its giant ears clearly visible. Native to Jala, in the state of Nayarit, on the Pacific coast of Mexico, this maize is famed for producing the world's largest ears.
Pure seed production crop of the CIMMYT synthetic-derived wheat variety Chuanmai 104 intercropped with maize.

Maize ears and seed of the Mexican landrace *Conico Norteño*. It is richly variable, showing white, yellow, red, and variegated colorations. The ears are dent in type and conical in shape, hence the name *conico*.
Cristina García and her daughter in their Milpa
Crossing the river
Four generations of female farmers of Chiapas
Family legacy

A CIMMYT field worker demonstrates the emasculation of a wheat spike. The spikelets are cut open, exposing the insides of the florets, and the anthers are removed with with forceps, creating *female* heads for use in crossing.
Hilda Castro in her ranch
Isabel Pérex Vázquez of Santa Ana, Oaxaca
Maize transformation
María Esther Rivas, head of small seed company Bidasem, visits seed processing plant
Maize hillside
Mexican farmer J. Isabel Rafael Moncada stands in his maize plot, in Jala, Nayarit, on the Pacific coast of Mexico. At 77 years of age, he has been growing maize for more than 70 years.
Mexican farmer Francisco Javier Balderas Espinoza checks the progress of wheat in his field, in the central Mexican plains region known as the Bajío.
Monica Mezzalama, head of CIMMYT's Seed Health Laboratory (SHL), talks to participants in a weeklong seed health workshop.
Women of Pueblo Nuevo
Women and Nixtamal
María Esther Rivas, director general of the small seed company Bidasem, visits a wheat field to check on its progress.
Workers at CIMMYT's El Batán, Mexico headquarters, carefully sorting maize seed before it is bagged and packed for distribution to partners.
A technician (left) from the ASGROW seed company undertakes a practical test on conservation agriculture (CA) at CIMMYT's El Batán headquarters, Mexico.
Transplanting winter wheat types to the screenhouse.
The Norman E. Borlaug Experiment Station), near Ciudad Obregón, in the state of Sonora, northern Mexico.
Wheat genetic diversity.

Participants in CIMMYT's 2011 advanced-level Wheat Improvement and Pathology training program, guided by CIMMYT wheat breeder Sukhwinder Singh (left), examine and take notes on seedling infection type in response to wheat leaf rust, stripe rust and stem rust.
Strenghtening capacity of maize technicians in Mozambique
Transporting maize
Bishnu Maya, Nepali farmer, has food all year round and can send children to school thanks to participatory evaluation of improved maize
A woman shells maize cobs during pretesting for the survey *Adoption of Improved Maize Varieties and the Impact of Community Based Seed Production in the Hills of Nepal* in Kavre district, Nepal.
A group of women farmers from Belhara village, Dhankuta district, in the mid-hills of Nepal, including Bishnu Maya (right) and her family and neighbors.
An improved wheat variety grows in the field in Islamabad, Pakistan.
Ladybug on improved wheat growing in Pakistan
Maize in the field in Islamabad, Pakistan, being grown for use as fodder for livestock.

A seed vendor with his wares, near Islamabad, Pakistan. For improved crop varieties to reach the farmers who need them, they usually must first reach local vendors like these, who form an essential link in the chain between researchers, seed producers, and farmers.
Emerging wheat spike from CIMMYT wheat nurseries planted at the National Agricultural Research Center in Islamabad, Pakistan.

Isaka Mashauri, managing director of Tanzanian seed company and long-term CIMMYT partner Tanseed International, showing the performance of the TAN 250 maize variety on one of the company’s demonstration plots, in Morogoro, Tanzania. These plots allow farmers to observe the attributes of different varieties in the field.
Hand fertilization in Tanzania
A farmer in Morogoro, Tanzania, shows the effects of drought on her maize crop.
Pichet Grudloyma, senior maize breeder at the Thai Department of Agriculture’s Nakhon Sawan Field Crops Research Center, shows off maize hybrids being tested on the center's drought screening plots.
For farmer Mary Sikirwayi, maize is life to her and her family, and she grows a number of varieties. Mostly she eats white maize, which she grinds and cooks to produce Zimbabwe’s staple food, sadza.
Mother and child, Pindukai village, Shamva District, Mashonaland Central, Zimbabwe.

A researcher harvests ears of an insect-resistant transgenic maize line at the close of the 2005 growing season. The lines were grown under strict biosafety and security controls in collaborative trials carried out on an open quarantine site with the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI), as part of CIMMYT's Insect Resistant Maize for Africa (IRMA) project.

Research workers harvest ears of an insect-resistant transgenic maize line at the close of the 2005 growing season. Ears of each line are carefully placed in a tray to await on-site shelling and recording of data. The lines were grown under strict biosafety and security controls in collaborative trials carried out on an open quarantine site with the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI), as part of CIMMYT's Insect Resistant Maize for Africa (IRMA) project.

CIMMYT and Kenya Agricultural Research Institute (KARI) staff work together to plant seed of insect-resistant transgenic maize lines at an open quarantine site on 27 May 2005, as part of CIMMYT's Insect Resistant Maize for Africa (IRMA) project. This was the first genetically modified maize grown in sub-Saharan Africa outside of South Africa. The packets of seed were kept and brought to the site in locked boxes, one of many careful biosafety and security measures.

A woman makes roti, an unleavened flatbread made with wheat flour and eaten as a staple food, at her home in the village of Chapor, in the district of Dinajpur, Bangladesh. Families like hers eat better thanks to improved varieties and farmer training from CIMMYT and its partners in Bangladesh.

A woman makes roti, an unleavened flatbread made with wheat flour and eaten as a staple food, at her home in the village of Chapor, in the district of Dinajpur, Bangladesh. Families like hers eat better thanks to improved varieties and farmer training from CIMMYT and its partners in Bangladesh.

A farmer pauses as she goes about her work in the village of Baikunthapur, Chirirbandar, Bangladesh, typical of the rural areas where CIMMYT is having an impact in improving the livelihoods of small farmers.

A handful of maize seed, especially precious because it is of the improved, drought tolerant variety TAN 250, which yields even in times of drought. This was developed and registered for sale in Tanzania through CIMMYT's Drought Tolerant Maize for Africa (DTMA) project, in partnership with Tanzanian seed company Tanseed International Limited. It is based on material from CIMMYT-Zimbabwe, CIMMYT-Mexico, and Tanzania.
Stewards Globe Acting Chief Executive Officer Stephanie Angomwile displays bags of Afriseeds bean seed at the company's warehouse in Lusaka, Zambia.

*This photo was taken at a Sustainable Intensification of Maize-Legume Systems for Food Security in Eastern and Southern Africa (SIMLESA) site in Kasungu, Malawi, after a 30-minute storm. It shows how residues on the soil surface help conserve water and reduce erosion.
Any Chandida harvest maize cobs
Branched spikes at maturity
Breakfast time
Bringing home the harvest by ox cart
A customer chooses bread in a small shop in Dinajpur, Bangladesh.
Bags of certified seed of ZM523 at Kambondo farm in Angola. ZM523 is an open-pollinated variety that is adapted to the local conditions in Angola.
A child drinks water from a pump in fields close to the Pusa site of the Borlaug Institute for South Asia (BISA), in the Indian state of Bihar.
Club type spikes red color

Dr. P.K Malaker, principal scientific officer, examines wheat samples for signs of fungal growth in the plant pathology laboratory of the Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute's Wheat Research Centre in Dinajpur.
A Bangladeshi scientist at work in the plant pathology laboratory of the Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute's Wheat Research Centre in Dinajpur.

Contrast between maize ears of different varieties in Morogoro, Tanzania. From left to right they are: traditional variety Asili, improved variety TMV 1 (both currently grown by farmers), and improved, drought tolerant variety, TAN 250.
Covering some spikes from bird damage at El Batán, Texcoco
Agricultural seed on sale by a vendor near Islamabad, Pakistan.

Yoseph Beyene, CIMMYT maize breeder (right), talks to other partners in the Drought Tolerant Maize for Africa (DTMA) project, during a field visit to the project's drought screening site at the the Kenya Agricultural Research Institute's Kiboko Research Station.
An attendant displays KDV1 drought-tolerant seed at the Dryland Seed Company shop in Machakos, Kenya.
Durum wheat landrace.
Paul Musembi Katiku, a field worker based in Kiboko, Kenya, weighs maize cobs harvested from a low nitrogen trial.
Girls in Nepal, beneficiaries of improved maize
Near Zewai, in the maize belt of Ethiopia’s Central Rift Valley, a mother and daughter transport maize grain to market by donkey cart.
A Bangladeshi farmer of Chapor village in the district of Dinajpur demonstrates how she and her husband have started storing their wheat grain in repurposed metal drums.
Improved maize benefits children
Lead farmer Elphas Chinyanga inspecting conservation agriculture plots.
Lovemore Chigumadzi inspects drought tolerant maize.
Maize pre-harvest with excellent results.
Transporting maize stover from the farm to the homestead.
A baker makes fresh naan roti on a street stall in Dinajpur, Bangladesh. These are a type of traditional flatbread made with wheat flour.
Maliamu Joni and Ruth Andrea harvesting drought tolerant maize.
A mother and child in Embu district, Kenya. Their community is benefitting from metal silos for maize grain storage.
Packing nursury seed at the Kiboko Experiment Station.
Plots showing genetic diversity of the wheat collection at El Batán.
Preparing a traditional maize dish.
Processed maize stover.

A seed store at Ukulima Farm in South Africa. The farm produces foundation seed of improved, drought tolerant (DT) maize varieties on a large scale and at high precision, as part of CIMMYT's Drought Tolerant Maize for Africa (DTMA) project
Sacks of seed are piled up ready for sale by a seed vendor, near Islamabad, Pakistan.
Chumki Mondol is a female farmer from Rajbari District, Bangaldesh. She used seeder fertilizer drills to plant wheat on her fields.
CIMMYT leads global research and development in quality protein maize (QPM), a nutritionally-enhanced type of maize that can help alleviate a lack of protein in poor diets.
Serving a traditional maize porridge.
Spraying maize for seed production.
Starting the kitchen fire.
Storing seed to bring better yields to farmers in Bangladesh
A researcher checks up on wheat seed stored in a climate-controlled warehouse at the Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute's Wheat Research Centre (WRC) in Dinajpur.
The tremendous diversity of Turkish wheat landraces collected in 2012.
The tremendous diversity of Turkish wheat landraces collected in 2012.
Workers winnow cow peas harvested at the doubled haploid facility in Kiboko, Kenya.
